body:
By their nature, rogues are varied and versatile. There are rogues who haunt the city, those who stalk the forest, and those who serve as agents of law. Wherever there is space for someone to make her mark with agility and wit, the rogue is there, using her wide range of skills and abilities to make a place for herself, whether openly or through cunning and subterfuge. And where a rogue's natural cunning and quick thinking aren't enough to win the day, well—there's always the option of a knife in the back.

The following rogue themes represent some of the most popular and effective roguish archetypes. Each archetype comes with one or more class features that must be taken. In addition, each archetype includes a number of new rogue talent suggestions that, while not mandatory, help to flesh out the character. Rogue talents and advanced rogue talents marked with an asterisk (*) in the archetype sections can be found in the Pathfinder RPG Core Rulebook.
name: Rogue

sections.body: The following new rogue talents can be taken by any rogue who meets the prerequisites. Note that rogue talents marked with a double asterisk (**) in this list add effects to a rogue's sneak attack. Only one of these talents can be applied to an individual attack, and the decision must be made before the attack roll is made.
sections.name: Rogue Talents
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents

sections.body: Once per day, when the rogue misses with an attack on a flanked opponent, she can designate a single ally who is also flanking the target that her attack missed. That ally can make a single melee attack against the opponent as an immediate action.
sections.name: Assault Leader
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Assault Leader

sections.body: When the rogue deals sneak attack damage against an opponent, that opponent takes a –2 penalty on attack rolls against the rogue for 1d4 rounds.
sections.name: Befuddling Strike**
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Befuddling Strike**

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent can craft simple but effective camouflage from the surrounding foliage. The rogue needs 1 minute to prepare the camouflage, but once she does, it is good for the rest of the day or until the rogue fails a saving throw against an area effect spell that deals fire, cold, or acid damage, whichever comes first. The rogue gains a +4 bonus on Stealth checks while within terrain that matches the foliage used to make the camouflage. This ability cannot be used in areas without natural foliage.
sections.name: Camouflage
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Camouflage

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent makes a Perception check to hear the details of a conversation or to find concealed or secret objects (including doors and traps), she gains a +4 bonus.
sections.name: Canny Observer
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Canny Observer

sections.body: Once per day, the rogue can roll two dice while making a Diplomacy check, and take the better result. She must choose to use this talent before making the Diplomacy check. A rogue can use this ability one additional time per day for every 5 rogue levels she possesses.
sections.name: Charmer
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Charmer

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can use Bluff or Diplomacy in place of Intimidate to force an opponent to act friendly toward her.
sections.name: Coax Information
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Coax Information

sections.body: A rogue who selects this talent gains Improved Steal as a bonus feat.
sections.name: Combat Swipe
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Combat Swipe

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can use a swift action to set off any trap within 30 feet that she constructed.
sections.name: Cunning Trigger
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Cunning Trigger

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can make sneak attacks with subtle flourishes that disorient and distract her enemy. When she hits a creature with a melee attack that deals sneak attack damage, she can forgo the additional damage to cause the creature to become flat-footed against one target of her choosing until the beginning of her next turn. The rogue cannot designate herself as the creature gaining the benefit of this talent. Creatures with uncanny dodge are immune to distracting attack.
sections.name: Distracting Attack**
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Distracting Attack**

sections.body: When making jump checks, the rogue is always considered to have a running start. Also, when the rogue deliberately falls, a DC 15 Acrobatics check allows her to ignore the first 20 feet fallen, instead of the first 10 feet.
sections.name: Expert Leaper
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Expert Leaper

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent can roll two dice while making a Sleight of Hand check and take the better result. She must choose to use this talent before making the Sleight of Hand check. A rogue can use this ability one additional time per day for every 5 rogue levels she possesses.
sections.name: Fast Fingers
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Fast Fingers

sections.body: After successfully making a sneak attack or Sleight of Hand check, a rogue with this talent can spend a move action to take the withdraw action. She can move no more than her speed during this movement.
sections.name: Fast Getaway
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Fast Getaway

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can use the Disable Device skill to attempt to open a lock as a standard action instead of a full-round action.
sections.name: Fast Picks
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Fast Picks

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can use Perception to follow tracks as per the Survival skill.
sections.name: Follow Clues
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Follow Clues

sections.body: A rogue with this talent who has at least one rank in Linguistics gains four additional languages. A rogue with this talent who does not have any ranks in Linguistics gains two additional languages. If the rogue later gains ranks in Linguistics, she gains two additional languages, to a total of four additional languages above those granted by the Linguistics skill itself.
sections.name: Guileful Polyglot
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Guileful Polyglot

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent can roll two dice while making a Sense Motive check, and take the better result. She must choose to use this talent before making the Sense Motive check. A rogue can use this ability one additional time per day for every 5 rogue levels she possesses.
sections.name: Hard to Fool
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Hard to Fool

sections.body: Once per day, the rogue can roll two dice while making a Bluff check, and take the better result. She must choose to use this talent before making the Bluff check. A rogue can use this ability one additional time per day for every five rogue levels she possesses.
sections.name: Honeyed Words
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Honeyed Words

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can apply poison to a weapon in such a way that it is effective for two successful attacks instead of one. The poison has a reduced effect, however, and saves made against the poison receive a +2 circumstance bonus. Applying poison in this way requires a full-round action, or a standard action if the rogue has the swift poison talent.
sections.name: Lasting Poison
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Lasting Poison

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent fails a Climb check by 5 or more, she can immediately make another Climb check at the surface's base DC +10. If successful, she stops her fall by clinging onto the surface. The rogue does not take falling damage when she stops her fall in this manner.
sections.name: Nimble Climber
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Nimble Climber

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent hits a creature with a melee attack that deals sneak attack damage, the rogue gains a +1 dodge bonus to AC for each sneak attack die rolled for 1 round.
sections.name: Offensive Defense**
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Offensive Defense**

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent can roll two dice while making an Acrobatics check, and take the better result. She must choose to use this talent before making the Acrobatics check. A rogue can use this ability one additional time per day for every 5 rogue levels she possesses.
sections.name: Peerless Maneuver
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Peerless Maneuver

sections.body: Once per day, when a rogue with this talent hits a creature with a melee attack, she can move up to 30 feet without provoking attacks of opportunity. The movement must end in a space adjacent to the creature hit with the melee attack.
sections.name: Positioning Attack
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Positioning Attack

sections.body: Whenever a rogue with this talent takes a full attack action, she can elect to take a –2 penalty on all attack rolls until the start of her next turn. If an attack during this time is a sneak attack, she treats all 1s on the sneak attack damage dice as 2s.
sections.name: Powerful Sneak**
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Powerful Sneak**

sections.body:
A rogue with this talent can use the items at hand and seemingly innocuous material hidden on her person to create startlingly effective disguises, reducing the amount of time it takes to create a disguise using the Disguise skill.

The time needed for the rogue to alter her appearance in this manner is based on the complexity of the disguise, as noted on the following table. The times are cumulative, so if a female rogue wants to disguise herself as a male of a different race, that takes 2 minutes.
sections.name: Quick Disguise
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Quick Disguise

sections.body:
DisguiseTime
Minor details only1 full-round action
Disguise as a different gender1 minute
Disguise as a different race1 minute
Disguise as a different age category1 minute
Disguise as a different size category1 minute
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Quick Disguise/Disguise
sections.name: Disguise

sections.body: As a full-round action, a rogue with this talent can set a simple trap with a CR no greater than 1/2 her rogue level. To do this, she must purchase the components, spend the required time constructing the trap in advance, and have its components at hand. The type of trap that can be constructed in this way is subject to GM discretion.
sections.name: Quick Trapsmith
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Quick Trapsmith

sections.body: A rogue with this talent may treat her intitiative roll as a 20 for a surprise round, regardless of her initiative, but she may only take an attack action with a ranged weapon. Her normal initiative roll is used in subsequent rounds. If two or more rogues possess this talent, their initiative determines the order in which they act, but they all go before any other creature. If a rogue is prevented from acting in the surprise round, this talent has no effect.
sections.name: Snap Shot
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Snap Shot

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can apply her sneak attack damage on ranged attacks targeting foes within 30 feet that benefit from concealment. Foes with total concealment are still immune.
sections.name: Sniper's Eye
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Snipers Eye

sections.body: A rogue who selects this talent gains Intimidating Prowess as a bonus feat.
sections.name: Strong Impression
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Strong Impression

sections.body: A rogue with this talent adds Heal and Survival to her list of class skills.
sections.name: Survivalist
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Survivalist

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can apply poison to a weapon as a move action, instead of a standard action.
sections.name: Swift Poison
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Talents/Swift Poison

sections.body: The following new advanced rogue talents can be selected by any rogue of 10th level or higher who meets the prerequisites.
sections.name: Advanced Rogue Talents
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents

sections.body: Once per day, when the rogue would be reduced to 0 or fewer hit points by a melee attack, she can take a 5-foot step as an immediate action. If the movement takes her out of the reach of the attack, she takes no damage from the attack. The rogue is staggered for 1 round on her next turn.
sections.name: Another Day
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Another Day

sections.body: A rogue with this talent can apply two doses of poison to a weapon at once. These can be separate poisons, in which case they both affect the target individually, or two doses of the same toxin, in which case the poisons' frequency is extended by 50% and the save DC increases by +2. This talent is an exception to the rule that injury poisons can only be delivered one dose at a time.
sections.name: Deadly Cocktail
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Deadly Cocktail

sections.body: Whenever a rogue with this talent uses the powerful sneak rogue talent, she treats all 1s and 2s on the sneak attack damage dice as 3s. A rogue must have the powerful sneak rogue talent before choosing this talent.
sections.name: Deadly Sneak**
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Deadly Sneak**

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent hits a creature with a melee attack that deals sneak attack damage, the target cannot take a 5-foot step until the beginning of the rogue's next turn.
sections.name: Entanglement of Blades**
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Entanglement of Blades**

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent uses Acrobatics to move at full speed through a threatened square without provoking an attack of opportunity, the DC of the Acrobatics check does not increase by 10.
sections.name: Fast Tumble
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Fast Tumble

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent constructs a mechanical trap, she only pays 75% of the normal cost.
sections.name: Frugal Trapsmith
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Frugal Trapsmith

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent can designate a single enemy she is adjacent to as her prey. Until the end of her next turn, she can add her sneak attack damage to all attacks made against her prey, even if she is not flanking it or it is not flat-footed.
sections.name: Hunter's Surprise
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Hunters Surprise

sections.body: Once per day, the rogue can forgo her sneak attack damage to attempt to knock out an opponent. She must declare the use of knock-out blow before she makes the attack. If the attack hits, it does normal damage, but instead of dealing sneak attack damage (and instead of any effect that triggers when the rogue deals sneak attack damage), the target falls unconscious for 1d4 rounds. A successful Fortitude save reduces this effect to staggered for 1 round. The DC of this save is equal to 10 + 1/2 the rogue's level + the rogue's Intelligence modifier.
sections.name: Knock-Out Blow
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Knock-Out Blow

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent gains a +10 bonus on a single Disguise check.
sections.name: Master of Disguise
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Master of Disguise

sections.body: Once per day, when a rogue with this talent is hit with a melee attack, she can redirect the attack to strike at an adjacent creature with a free action. The creature targeted must be within melee reach of the attack that hit the rogue, and the creature that made the attack against the rogue must make a new attack roll against the new target.
sections.name: Redirect Attack
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Redirect Attack

sections.body: When a rogue with this talent uses the Stealth skill to snipe, she only suffers a –10 penalty on the Stealth check, instead of –20.
sections.name: Stealthy Sniper
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Stealthy Sniper

sections.body: Once per day, a rogue with this talent can reroll a Knowledge, Sense Motive, or Perception skill check to try to gain new or better information from the roll. This reroll can be made any time during the same day as the original check.
sections.name: Thoughtful Reexamining
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Advanced Rogue Talents/Thoughtful Reexamining
pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes

sections.body: Agility and daring are both excellent rogue traits, and their confluence can create spectacular feats of acrobatics. Whether they are daring thieves, infiltrating assassins, or intrepid spies, proper training in acrobatics is a valuable boon for rogues.
sections.name: Acrobat
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Acrobat

sections.body: At 1st level, an acrobat does not suffer any armor check penalties on Acrobatics, Climb, Fly, Sleight of Hand, or Stealth skill checks while wearing light armor. When she is not wearing armor, she gains a +2 competency bonus on Acrobatics and Fly skill checks. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Expert Acrobat
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Acrobat/Expert Acrobat

sections.body: At 3rd level, an acrobat can reroll any Acrobatics, Climb, or Fly skill check she has just made. This reroll is made at a –5 penalty. She must take the second result, even if it is worse. An acrobat can use this ability only once on any given skill check. She can use this ability once per day at 3rd level, plus one additional time per day for every 3 levels beyond 3rd. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Second Chance
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Acrobat/Second Chance

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the acrobat archetype: expert leaper, ledge walker*, nimble climber, peerless maneuver, rogue crawl*, and stand up*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the acrobat archetype: defensive roll*, fast getaway, fast tumble, and improved evasion*.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Adept at infiltration, trap removal, and lock picking, burglars prey on the homes of the wealthy and forgotten tombs alike. Such riches are guarded with vicious traps and hazards, but the devious mind of the burglar allows her to find such dangers and avoid them.
sections.name: Burglar
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Burglar

sections.body: At 4th level, whenever a burglar attempts to disarm a trap using Disable Device, she does not spring the trap unless she fails by 10 or more. If she does set off a trap she was attempting to disarm, she adds double her trap sense bonus to avoid the trap. This ability replaces uncanny dodge.
sections.name: Careful Disarm
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Burglar/Careful Disarm

sections.body: At 8th level, whenever a burglar is detected while using Stealth, she can immediately attempt a Bluff skill check opposed by the Sense Motive skill of the creature that spotted her. If this check succeeds, the target assumes that the noise was something innocent and disregards the detection. This only functions if the creature cannot see the rogue. This ability can only be used once during a given Stealth attempt. If the same creature detects the rogue's presence again, the ability has no effect. This ability replaces improved uncanny dodge.
sections.name: Distraction
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Burglar/Distraction

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the burglar archetype: fast picks, fast stealth*, nimble climber, quick disable*, and trap spotter*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the burglar archetype: knock-out blow, skill mastery*, and thoughtful reexamining.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Everyone who lives in the city understands that a wealthy man stays wealthy by guarding his purse while wandering the streets and markets. Cutpurses are often trained by guilds to collect the guild's tax from local businesses on a daily basis, whether through intimidation or pickpocketing. Some find themselves taking up the mantle of adventurer, and their talents are generally appreciated in this role, but the cutpurse is still the first person her companions look to when an item goes missing.
sections.name: Cutpurse
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Cutpurse

sections.body: When a cutpurse makes a Sleight of Hand check to take something from a creature, the target makes its Perception check before the rogue makes her Sleight of Hand check, and the rogue knows the Perception check result. She can decide whether or not to make the check based on the results of the target's Perception check. If the rogue elects not to make the check, she can make a Bluff check, opposed by the target's Sense Motive, to prevent the target from noticing the attempt. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Measure the Mark
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Cutpurse/Measure the Mark

sections.body: At 3rd level, as a full-round action, a cutpurse can make an attack and also make a Sleight of Hand check to steal something from the target of the attack. If the attack deals sneak attack damage, the rogue can use Sleight of Hand to take an item from the creature during combat; otherwise this ability can only be used in a surprise round before the target has acted. If the attack is successful, the target takes a –5 penalty on the Perception check to notice the theft. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Stab and Grab
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Cutpurse/Stab and Grab

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the cutpurse archetype: combat swipe, fast fingers, fast getaway, hard to fool, minor magic*, slow reactions*, and surprise attack*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the cutpurse archetype: crippling strike*, fast tumble, and skill mastery*.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Not all rogues work against the law. Investigators use their skills to serve the law, often in the employ of nobles or in the pursuit of noble causes. In some cities cabals of investigators work for rulers or bureaucracies, but often an investigator is a free agent who pursues whatever mysteries come across her path. Of course, not all investigators serve the law. Crime lords and guildmasters often have squads of investigators serving their own nefarious purposes.
sections.name: Investigator
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Investigator

sections.body: An investigator can roll twice on any Diplomacy check made to gather information, and receives the information for both results. This takes the same amount of time as one check. If the lesser of the two checks reveals false information, the rogue is aware of it. False information is not revealed in this way if the people she questioned do not know it to be false. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Follow Up
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Investigator/Follow Up

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the investigator archetype: coax information, fast picks, follow clues, hard to fool, and minor magic*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the investigator archetype: hunter's surprise, slippery mind*, and thought reexamining.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Some consider poisoning an evil act. The poisoner knows poison is just a tool toward an end, and is no different than any other weapon. Some poisoners see themselves as great equalizers, as they are able to craft weapons that the weakest of creatures can wield to devastating effect, but most have no lofty delusions about their work.
sections.name: Poisoner
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Poisoner

sections.body: At 1st level, a poisoner is trained in the use of poison and cannot accidentally poison herself when applying poison to a blade. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Poison Use
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Poisoner/Poison Use

sections.body: At 3rd level, a poisoner can use Craft (alchemy) to change the type of a poison. This requires 1 hour of work with an alchemist's lab and a Craft (alchemy) skill check with a DC equal to the poison's DC. If successful, the poison's type changes to contact, ingested, inhaled, or injury. If the check fails, the poison is ruined. The poisoner also receives a bonus on Craft (alchemy) skill checks when working with poison equal to 1/2 her rogue level. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Master Poisoner
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Poisoner/Master Poisoner

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the poisoner archetype: distracting attack, lasting poison, surprise attack*, swift poison, and weapon training*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the poisoner archetype: deadly cocktail, hunter's surprise, and opportunist*.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: The rake is a rogue who is open about her skills and talents, often to the point of being boastful. Usually she has the protection of an important figure who finds her services useful, but sometimes her bravado is enough to keep enemies away. She is often used as a face for the group for diplomacy, gathering information, negotiations, or to gain the most lucrative contracts and quests from local authorities.
sections.name: Rake
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Rake

sections.body: When a rake hits an opponent and deals sneak attack damage, she can forgo 1d6 points of that damage and make a free Intimidate check to demoralize the foe. For every additional 1d6 points of sneak attack damage she forgoes, she receives a +5 circumstance bonus on this check. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Bravado's Blade
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Rake/Bravados Blade

sections.body: At 3rd level, a rake gains a +1 morale bonus on Bluff and Diplomacy checks. This bonus increases by +1 for every 3 levels beyond 3rd. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Rake's Smile
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Rake/Rakes Smile

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the rake archetype: befuddling strike, charmer, honeyed words, and surprise attack*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the rake archetype: another day, redirect attack, and skill mastery*.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Not all rogues live in the city. Scouts frequently roam the wilderness, often banding together as bandits, but sometimes serving as guides, as trailblazers, or as companions to a ranger or barbarian warrior. More comfortable with sneaking and hiding outdoors, the scout is still effective in the city and the dungeon.
sections.name: Scout
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Scout

sections.body: At 4th level, whenever a scout makes a charge, her attack deals sneak attack damage as if the target were flat-footed. Foes with uncanny dodge are immune to this ability. This ability replaces uncanny dodge.
sections.name: Scout's Charge
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Scout/Scouts Charge

sections.body: At 8th level, whenever a scout moves more than 10 feet in a round and makes an attack action, the attack deals sneak attack damage as if the target was flat-footed. If the scout makes more than one attack this turn, this ability only applies to the first attack. Foes with uncanny dodge are immune to this ability. This ability replaces improved uncanny dodge.
sections.name: Skirmisher
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Scout/Skirmisher

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the scout archetype: assault leader, camouflage, cunning trigger, survivalist, and trap spotter*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the scout archetype: hunter's surprise, skill mastery*, and stealthy sniper.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Some say that the sniper is the worst kind of assassin: a killer who waits silently in the shadows and then strikes from a distance without remorse. Snipers, of course, understand that such protestations about “cowardice” and “honor” regarding their profession are in fact merely the bleatings of sheep fearing the slaughter and pay them no heed. Most snipers take pride in their formidable abilities, which allow them to take life quickly, quietly, and efficiently, then disappear into their surroundings without a trace.
sections.name: Sniper
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Sniper

sections.body: At 1st level, a sniper halves all range increment penalties when making ranged attacks with a bow or crossbow. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Accuracy
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Sniper/Accuracy

sections.body: At 3rd level, a sniper increases the range at which she can apply her sneak attack damage by 10 feet. This range increases by 10 feet for every 3 levels after 3rd. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Deadly Range
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Sniper/Deadly Range

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the sniper archetype: camouflage, snap shot, sniper's eye, and weapon training*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the sniper archetype: defensive roll*, master of disguise, and stealthy sniper.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: The best spies are like chameleons, but not only can they change their appearances to fit the situation, they can also change their personalities, allegiances, and even loves if that's what it takes to achieve their clandestine goals. Spies are the ultimate manipulators, and even those who commission their services sometimes find that they've merely served the spies' own interests.
sections.name: Spy
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Spy

sections.body: Whenever a spy uses Bluff to attempt to deceive someone, she gains a bonus on the opposed roll equal to 1/2 her rogue level (minimum +1). This bonus does not apply to feint attempts or attempts to pass secret messages. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Skilled Liar
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Spy/Skilled Liar

sections.body: A 3rd level, a spy is trained in the use of poison and cannot accidentally poison herself when applying poison to a blade. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Poison Use
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Spy/Poison Use

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the spy archetype: canny observer, guileful polyglot, honeyed words, major magic*, minor magic*, and quick disguise.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the spy archetype: crippling strike*, master of disguise, and stealthy sniper.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: A paragon of mobile swordplay, the swashbuckler is a rogue who focuses almost exclusively on honing her skill at arms and perfecting daring acrobatic moves and elaborate flourishes that border on performance.
sections.name: Swashbuckler
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Swashbuckler

sections.body: At 1st level, the swashbuckler may select one martial weapon to add to her list of weapon proficiencies. In addition, she may take the combat trick rogue talent up to two times. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Martial Training
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Swashbuckler/Martial Training

sections.body: At 3rd level, a swashbuckler gains a +1 morale bonus on Acrobatics checks and saving throws against fear. This bonus increases by +1 for every 3 levels beyond 3rd. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Daring
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Swashbuckler/Daring

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the swashbuckler archetype: offensive defense, positioning attack, powerful sneak, and weapon training*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the swashbuckler archetype: crippling strike*, entanglement of blades, and redirect attack.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Some criminals steal with finesse, their victims only discovering the crime when the rogue is long gone and the coin already spent. A thug, on the other hand, cares nothing for finesse. Through both threat and violence, the thug gets what she wants by the promise of force, and has no problem making good on that promise as needed.
sections.name: Thug
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Thug

sections.body: Whenever a thug successfully uses Intimidate to demoralize a creature, the duration of the shaken condition is increased by 1 round. In addition, if the target is shaken for 4 or more rounds, the thug can instead decide to make the target frightened for 1 round. This ability replaces trapfinding.
sections.name: Frightening
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Thug/Frightening

sections.body: At 3rd level, whenever a thug deals sneak attack damage, she can choose to forgo 1d6 points of sneak attack damage to make the target sickened for a number of rounds equal to 1/2 her rogue level. This ability does not stack with itself—only the most recent duration applies. This ability replaces trap sense.
sections.name: Brutal Beating
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Thug/Brutal Beating

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the thug archetype: offensive defense, powerful sneak, strong impression, and weapon training*.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the thug archetype: crippling strike*, deadly sneak, and knock-out blow.
sections.name: Advanced Talents

sections.body: Some rogues are not content with just disabling traps—they love to build them, finding a captivating beauty in the turning of gears and the slither of ropes over pulleys. The trapsmith may have started out putting together traps in order to better understand how to disable them, but for most, it's long since gone beyond that—they now relish the challenge of creating the perfect combat machine.
sections.name: Trapsmith
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Trapsmith

sections.body: At 4th level, whenever a trapsmith attempts to disarm a trap using Disable Device, she does not spring the trap unless she fails by 10 or more. If she does set off a trap she was attempting to disarm, she adds double her trap sense bonus to avoid the trap. This ability replaces uncanny dodge.
sections.name: Careful Disarm
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Trapsmith/Careful Disarm

sections.body: At 8th level, whenever a trapsmith disarms a trap using Disable Device, she can bypass it even if her check did not exceed the DC by 10 or more. If it is a magic trap that allows specific creatures to pass it without danger, she can modify which creatures it allows to pass, adding her allies and restricting enemies if she desires. This ability replaces improved uncanny dodge.
sections.name: Trap Master
sections.url: pfsrd://Advanced Players Guide/Rules/Core Classes/Rogue/Rogue Archetypes/Trapsmith/Trap Master

sections.body: The following rogue talents complement the trapsmith archetype: befuddling strike, cunning trigger, quick disable*, and quick trapsmith.
sections.name: Rogue Talents

sections.body: The following advanced rogue talents complement the trapsmith archetype: another day, frugal trapsmith, and skill mastery*.
sections.name: Advanced Talents
Rogue Archetypes
